metadata.synopsis: The player has burned their bridges. They attacked the Emperor, causing him to leave the Astral Prism as a foe, and they have no hammer to free Orpheus, as they need his protection against the influence of the Netherbrain. After a short pause to let the players feel the weight of their actions, Raphael appears before them, with a new deal: accept the hammer from Raphael, freeing Orpheus in exchange for giving him the Crown. At this point, the player has no other option except for a game over.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Load END_Mainoe end_startillithidoptionsfollow the Emperor to the assimilation point (near Orpheus)Attack the EmperorWait for Raphael to appear

50.speaker: Raphael
50.context: NodeContext: amused - he's just appeared to the players in a climactic moment when they thought they were doomed, and he has the upper hand

74.speaker: Raphael
74.text: When the ballads are composed and the history books are written, they'll commemorate your battle across the High Hall.
74.context: NodeContext: spinning a grand tale with a sting coming later

54.speaker: Raphael
54.text: The blows you struck against the gods themselves will echo down through the ages.
54.context: NodeContext: spinning a grand tale with a sting coming later

52.speaker: Raphael
52.text: The great hero of Baldur's Gate! Conqueror of the Netherbrain. Your deeds will be timeless.
52.context: NodeContext: not quite sarcastic, but he's puffing up the players for a fall

59.speaker: Raphael
59.text: And nobody will ever know that your feeble-minded negligence almost doomed the world in the last moment.
59.context: NodeContext: and here's the sting - he just built up the players as heroes, but is reminding them that they have made a minor error that could doom them

1.context: CinematicNodeContext: |Raphael snaps his fingers and the hammer appears before him.|

29.speaker: Raphael
29.text: The Orphic Hammer. You misplaced it.

69.speaker: Raphael
69.text: Your absent-mindedness pains me more than your clumsy snooping in my home.

33.speaker: Raphael
33.text: But I'll make sure the bards don't hear about this little moment of negligence. After all - we're associates in this great endeavour.
33.context: NodeContext: at his most charmingly insidious

64.speaker: Raphael
64.text: It seems the aspiring heroes of Baldur's Gate have backed themselves into a rather uncomfortable corner.

58.speaker: Raphael
58.text: Listen. Tune your minds beyond the frequency of the Prism's psychic collapse, and you can hear the sonorous, metronomic tick before the final tock.

48.speaker: Raphael
48.text: The world's clock is winding down.

16.speaker: Raphael
16.text: The grand finale has arrived, my friends, and thanks to you, I have a ringside seat.

21.speaker: Raphael
21.text: How undignified. I prefer business to begging. You have brought yourself low.

17.speaker: Raphael
17.text: And not for the first time. Your clumsy snooping in my House of Hope did not go unnoticed - the stench of deceit lingers so.

38.speaker: Raphael
38.text: I have been more than generous in my dealings with you, and if you'd only listened, the brain would be dead, and you'd be sampling the contents of my wine cellar even now.

70.speaker: Raphael
70.text: We could have been allies, partners... friends.

62.speaker: Raphael
62.text: But that's all done with. Now, I dictate the terms, and you agree to them. Master and vassal.

75.speaker: Raphael
75.text: You're going to do exactly what I tell you to, or in mere moments, the thing you've dreaded will finally come to pass.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: Tell me what you need me to do.

35.speaker: Raphael
35.text: I provide the Orphic Hammer, with which you can free Prince Orpheus.

67.speaker: Raphael
67.text: And when the brain is defeated, you seize the Crown and give it to me. Refuse, and I'll take your souls instead.

73.speaker: Narrator
73.text: *So it comes to this - the devil's final offer. And your last chance to face the Netherbrain and survive.*

27.speaker: Narrator
27.text: *At any other moment, the Crown of Karsus might seem too high a price. But to a desperate soul, Raphael's offer might even be considered charitable.*

15.speaker: Raphael
15.text: Beautiful. With that single word you may have saved a billion lives - your own among them.

20.context: CinematicNodeContext: Raphael summons a floating contract, whcih appears in a burst of flames.

13.context: CinematicNodeContext: Tthe player signs the floating camera (back to camera), and then Raphael pops the Orphic Hammer into existance (also floating) and the player takes it.

31.speaker: Raphael
31.text: Free Orpheus and follow his lead. Then give that Netherbrain hell.

71.speaker: Raphael
71.text: I'll come to collect the Crown when you've triumphed.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: I don't like this, but I don't have a choice. Deal.

32.speaker: Raphael
32.text: You don't need to like it - you're doing the right thing.

9.speaker: Raphael
9.text: Why must you be so stubborn?

41.speaker: Raphael
41.text: If you refuse me, in mere moments, the thing that you've dreaded will finally come to pass.

5.speaker: Raphael
5.text: The city will burn - your world will die. But you will persist, a grey shadow. Without beauty, without heart, without self.

23.speaker: Raphael
23.text: Dwelling in the ashes of dead worlds or in the space between stars, you will wander, endless. One among billions.

76.speaker: Raphael
76.text: You have already become illithid, but you do not yet know what it is to be illithid. Soon, you will be a fragment of the hivemind, nothing more.

0.speaker: Raphael
0.text: A survivor. A remnant. An illithid.

57.speaker: Raphael
57.text: One of your companions is already lost - you will suffer the same fate.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: I'll find another way - I always do.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: I'd prefer to avoid that - what can I do?

7.speaker: Player
7.text: Sounds great - I might finally find some peace.

18.speaker: Raphael
18.text: That may be. When the screaming stops and your mind is gone, the rest, perhaps, is silence.

4.speaker: Raphael
4.text: Refuse me, and you'll soon know for sure.

39.speaker: Narrator
39.text: *He's telling the truth - you've never been more sure of anything.*

44.speaker: Player
44.text: What do you need me to do?

43.speaker: Player
43.text: Then maybe this is the end.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: Then maybe this is the end.

60.speaker: Raphael
60.text: Then in mere moments all that you've dreaded will finally come to pass.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: Planning to spend these last moments mocking me?

61.speaker: Raphael
61.text: I would love to, but you've already made quite a mockery of yourself.

55.speaker: Raphael
55.text: But I assure you, enjoying the spectacle will be quite beyond you.

56.speaker: Raphael
56.text: In mere moments, all that you have dreaded will come to pass.
